title: 105_s494
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" and it pertains to prisoner copayments for health care services. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" adds a new section to Chapter 303 of title 18, United States Code, regarding prisoner copayments for health care services. It defines terms like account, Director, health care provider, and health care visit. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" defines key terms such as Director (the Director of the Bureau of Prisons), health care provider (licensed to provide health care services), health care visit (prisoner's visit to a health care provider), and prisoner (person subject to incarceration). The term 'prisoner' refers to any person under incarceration, detention, or admission to a facility for criminal law violations. A 'qualified health care visit' excludes visits conducted during incarceration. The term 'qualified health care visit' excludes certain types of health care visits, such as those conducted during the incarceration intake process, annual examinations, emergency visits, and immunizations. The term 'qualified health care visit' excludes certain types of visits conducted during incarceration intake, annual examinations, emergency visits, immunizations, visits initiated by Bureau of Prisons staff, and visits resulting from referrals by prison officials. The Director shall waive copayments for health care services for prisoners who are under 18, pregnant, seriously mentally ill, permanently disabled, receive immunizations, have visits initiated by Bureau of Prisons staff, or are referred by prison officials. The Director will assess and collect a fee of $3 to $5 for each qualified health care visit, and up to $5 for certain health care services, excluding prisoners under 18, pregnant individuals, and those deemed seriously mentally ill or permanently disabled. The Director will assess and collect fees for health care services, including $3 to $5 for each qualified health care visit and up to $5 for prescription medications and specific health care visits. The Director will assess fees for prescription medications and health care visits, including those resulting from injuries inflicted by another prisoner. Fees will be collected from the prisoner receiving the services. The Director will assess fees for health care visits resulting from injuries inflicted by another prisoner. Fees will be collected from the responsible prisoner's account. The Director will assess fees for health care visits resulting from injuries inflicted by another prisoner, to be collected from the responsible prisoner's account. Fees will be collected on the date of the visit or through an installment payment plan if the account balance is insufficient. The Director will collect fees for health care visits from prisoners, either on the visit date or through an installment payment plan if the account balance is insufficient. Treatment cannot be refused due to financial reasons. The Director will establish an installment payment plan for prisoners to pay for health care visits. Treatment cannot be denied based on financial reasons, and collected fees will go to the Crime Victims' Fund. The Director will establish an installment payment plan for prisoners unable to pay health care fees. Amounts collected will be deposited into the Crime Victims' Fund. Reports to Congress on collected amounts will be submitted annually. The Director will submit annual reports to Congress on the amounts collected from prisoners under the Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act and analyze the impact on health care visits. Prisoner copayments for health care services are required under the Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act.
